metadata.case_name: Balak Ram & Ors. v. State of U.P.

facts.text: On May 27, 1971, Tribeni Sahai and Radhey were shot dead in Dataganj, District Budaun.
Balak Ram convicted under section 302 IPC by Sessions Judge Budaun and sentenced to death; also convicted under 337/149 and 148 IPC.
Sessions Judge acquitted Nathoo, Dr. R.P. Kohli, Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan, Kailash, and Ahmed Sayeed Khan alias Pearey Mian.

Allahabad High Court confirmed Balak Ram's conviction under 302 and 148 IPC, altered 337/149 to 307/149; convicted Nathoo, Dr. Kohli, Banney Khan under 302/149, 307/149, and 148 or 147 IPC, sentenced to life imprisonment.

Incident arose out of political rivalry between Congress R, Congress O, and Bharatiya Jan Sangh; Tribeni Sahai was Congress R MLA, Radhey his bodyguard; Balak Ram, Nathoo, Banney Khan Congress O; Dr. Kohli Jan Sangh President.

Elections to Town Area Committee Dataganj scheduled May 30, 1971; Balak Ram contesting Chairmanship on Congress O ticket vs. Dharam Pal (Congress R); Nathoo, Banney Khan contesting membership on Congress O.
District Magistrate promulgated section 144 CrPC order on May 24, 1971 prohibiting assembly of more than five and carrying arms.
Balak Ram led procession of 25 persons at 6.30 pm on May 27, 1971 defying section 144; clashed with Dharam Pal's group but dispersed by SHO Yogendra Sharma.

At 9.15 pm on May 27, six accused with 15-20 followers canvassed; went to lane near Tribeni Sahai's house; raised offensive slogans; Tribeni protested; Dr. Kohli, Banney Khan, Pearey Mian exhorted Balak Ram to fire; Balak Ram fired pistol hitting Tribeni Sahai on right scapular region.
Radhey ran to protect Tribeni; Balak Ram, Nathoo, Dr. Kohli fired 4-5 shots; Radhey hit on left back; Jhilmili and Ram Prakash injured on thigh and abdomen respectively.
Rajendra Kumar Misra (brother-in-law of Tribeni's brother Radhey Shyam Sharma, DIG) lodged FIR at 9.45 pm at police station 2 furlongs away.
Tribeni Sahai made dying declaration to Dharam Pal naming Balak Ram instigated by Banney Khan, Pearey Mian, Dr. Kohli.
SHO Yogendra Sharma recorded second dying declaration from Tribeni in car; tried to interrogate Radhey but unconscious.
Victims taken to Budaun Civil Hospital arriving 11.30 pm; Radhey declared dead; SDM Sada Ram recorded third dying declaration from Tribeni at 11.50 pm.
Tribeni died at 8.30 pm on May 28 at Mission Hospital Bareilly.
Postmortem on Radhey by Dr. A. Gupta on May 28: lacerated wound left axillary, bullet recovered.
Postmortem on Tribeni by Dr. S. Mitra on May 29: gunshot wound right scapular.
Jhilmili and Ram Prakash injuries examined by Dr. R.C. Bansal on May 28: thigh entry/exit, abdominal burn.
Dr. Kohli arrested 2.30 am May 28; revolver from wife, loaded, smelled freshly fired.
Banney Khan arrested 5 am May 28; Balak Ram, Nathoo, Pearey Mian surrendered May 29, June 7, June 11.
Balak Ram's pistol surrendered by father June 1.
Ballistic expert Shyam Narain: bullet from Radhey's body fired from Balak Ram's pistol; scene bullet from other weapon.
Appellants denied presence, knowledge of s.144; pleaded false implication due to political rivalry; Balak Ram, Nathoo alibi.
Dr. Kohli claimed taken to PS at 10.30 pm May 27, revolver taken from house later.
Civil suit by Banney Khan, Pearey Mian vs Tribeni pending since 1965.
Various prior criminal cases between parties: 307 IPC against Banney/Pearey, 120B by Tribeni, etc.
Eyewitnesses: Jhilmili (PW1), Ram Prakash (PW11), Rajendra Kumar Misra (PW13), Aryendra Nath (PW19).
FIR by Rajendra does not mention Jhilmili, Ram Prakash.
Jhilmili's relatives contested on Congress O; son got PAC job post-incident; bank deposit discrepancies.
Ram Prakash's father prosecuted by Tribeni for conspiracy.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court was justified in upholding the conviction of Balak Ram under section 302 IPC and the sentence of death.
Whether the High Court had good and sufficient reasons for interfering with the Sessions Court's order of acquittal in favour of Nathoo, Dr. R.P. Kohli and Banney Khan.

petitioner_arguments.text: Falsely implicated due to political rivalry; witnesses friends/relatives of Tribeni or pressured by police at instance of DIG Radhey Shyam.
Balak Ram alibi: at Lucknow from May 25.
Nathoo alibi: went to Chandausi morning May 27, returned May 29; feared shooting order by DIG.
Dr. Kohli: detained at PS 10.30 pm May 27, revolver taken later; no personal enmity.
Banney Khan implicated due to personal enmity, pending civil suit.
Dying declarations fabricated; eyewitnesses unreliable, mutual corroboration invalid; ballistic evidence infirm.

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution case: accused in procession raised slogans, exhorted Balak Ram to fire; fired shots killing Tribeni and Radhey, injuring Jhilmili and Ram Prakash; corroborated by eyewitnesses, dying declarations, ballistic evidence.
FIR prompt; eyewitnesses independent; dying declarations voluntary and consistent.

court_reasoning.text: Eyewitnesses (Jhilmili, Ram Prakash, Rajendra, Aryendra) not independent, infirmities: omissions in FIR, political links, unnatural conduct, prior enmities; cannot corroborate each other.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two reasonable views possible; Sessions acquittal reasonable, High Court should not interfere.

court_reasoning.text: Dying declarations unreliable: first not mentioned by eyewitnesses, second to IO unsafe, third when victim in shock, influenced by friends; no independent corroboration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not safe to act on uncorroborated dying declarations.

court_reasoning.text: No ballistic link to Dr. Kohli's revolver or Nathoo; Nathoo's name scored off dying declaration; Banney Khan old, only exhortation evidence weak.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Acquit Nathoo, Dr. Kohli, Banney Khan.

court_reasoning.text: Concurrent findings against Balak Ram; ballistic expert confirms bullet from his pistol killed Radhey; eyewitnesses natural on his role; alibi weak.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reason to interfere with concurrent conviction under 302 IPC.

court_reasoning.text: No provocation; Balak Ram fired pistol at unarmed victims after vulgar slogans protest.

holdings.text: High Court erred in reversing Sessions acquittal of Nathoo, Dr. Kohli, Banney Khan as two views possible; acquittal restored.
Concurrent conviction of Balak Ram under section 302 IPC upheld; death sentence confirmed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ramabhupala Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Supreme Court does not re-appraise concurrent findings of fact unless exceptional circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Jag v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court interferes with acquittal only if fails to apply correct principles; if two views possible, no interference.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhupendra Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: In death sentence reference, High Court must examine entire evidence independently.
High Court must consider defence evidence in confirmation of death sentence.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Convictions for murder, attempt to murder, rioting with deadly weapons, causing hurt by rash act in unlawful assembly.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibitory order, recording statements, reference for death sentence confirmation.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Police Regulations
statutes_cited.relevance: Dying declaration to be recorded in presence of two witnesses with declarant's signature.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeals; limited interference in criminal matters.

outcome.summary: Appeals of Nathoo, Dr. R.P. Kohli and Mohd. Sayeed Khan Banney Khan allowed; High Court convictions set aside, Sessions acquittal restored, to be released forthwith. Balak Ram's appeal dismissed; conviction and death sentence upheld.
outcome.relief_granted: Acquittal and release for three appellants; no relief for Balak Ram.

key_quotes.text: This Court would not therefore re-appraise the evidence unless... substantial and grave injustice has otherwise resulted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits SC interference with concurrent findings.

key_quotes.text: If two views of the evidence are reasonably possible the High Court ought not to interfere with the order of acquittal passed by the trial court.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Corroboration in such cases must be forthcoming from an independent source.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Eyewitnesses cannot corroborate each other due to infirmities.

key_quotes.text: Balak Ram was carrying a pistol and he fired from that pistol without any provocation either from Tribeni Sahai or from Radhey.
key_quotes.speaker: court
